messages.content: Don't make assumptions about what values to plug into functions. Ask for clarification if a user request is ambiguous.
I don’t have access to your location yet. Could you please share your current latitude and longitude so I can look up which city you’re in?
I don't have that info either.

I’m afraid I can’t look up your city without some location data. If you can share at least one of the following, I’ll be able to help:

• Your current latitude & longitude  
• A street address or intersection  
• A nearby landmark or postal (zip) code  

If you’re on a smartphone or computer, you can often get your GPS coordinates by opening your map app and tapping your “current location” marker. Let me know once you have something like that!
Can you try turning on the location service and figuring it out?

I’m not able to remotely turn on or access your device’s location services. You’ll need to enable or share your location yourself. Here are a couple of ways you can do that:

1. On a smartphone or tablet  
   – Go to Settings → Privacy (or Location Services) → enable Location.  
   – Then open your map app (Google Maps, Apple Maps, etc.), tap the “current location” dot, and read off the latitude & longitude.

2. In a web browser  
   – When prompted by this site to “allow location,” click “Allow.”  
   – If you missed the prompt, click the padlock (🔒) icon in your address bar, find “Location,” and set it to “Allow.”

Once you have your latitude & longitude (or even just a nearby street address or zip code), send it over and I’ll look up which city you’re in.
I can't seem to get any of that info myself. Do you have any other ideas?

Here are a few more ways you might be able to pin down your city. Once you have even a rough clue—an IP-based location, a description of your surroundings, a time zone offset, etc.—I can help you turn that into a city name.

1. Use an IP-based geolocation site  
   • In your browser, Google “what’s my IP” and note the address you get.  
   • Go to a free IP-lookup site (e.g. iplocation.net, whatismyipaddress.com) and it’ll give you an approximate city.

2. Ask your device’s built-in assistant  
   • On iOS: Say “Hey Siri, where am I?”  
   • On Android: Say “Hey Google, what’s my location?”  
   • On Windows/Mac: In Chrome/Firefox’s address bar, type `navigator.geolocation.getCurrentPosition` in the dev console under “Sensors” (advanced).

3. Check local signage or clues  
   • Look for street-sign names, store or restaurant names, bus/train lines, license-plate codes, or postal codes on mail/boxes.  
   • Note the language(s) on signs, currency on price-tags, mobile carrier name in your status bar, or local radio stations.

4. Find your time-zone offset  
   • What does your clock read compared to UTC? (e.g. UTC +2, UTC –5)  
   • Combine that with hemisphere clues (weather, latitude-style sunlight) to narrow it down.

5. Describe your surroundings to me  
   • Even a few landmarks, major roads, company names, or distinctive buildings can be enough for me to make an educated guess.

Pick whichever method you can manage, then share the result. I’ll turn that into your city right away.
